subject: Investing
title: Cash Flow: The Lifeblood of Rentals
description: A quick, practical guide to Cash Flow: The Lifeblood of Rentals.

hook.text: A landlord collects $1,800 in rent each month but pockets only $300 after all expenses.

buildup.text: Cash flow equals rental income minus mortgage, taxes, insurance, maintenance, and vacancy.

discovery.text: Positive cash flow means money left over each month; negative means you're paying out of pocket.

twist.text: A property can appreciate nicely yet still lose money monthly if expenses creep too high.

climax.text: Seasoned investors target at least $200 per month of positive cash flow per rental unit.

punchline.text: Appreciation is a bonus; cash flow keeps the lights on.

quiz.question: What does positive cash flow mean for a rental property?
